event.event_info: Conductor James Conlon leads a wonderful cast in the opening concert for Festival 2010. The miracle of the nativity is given a new life in John Adam's oratorio El Niño. Women's voices and experiences are central to the retelling of this story unusually told from a mother's perspective. Sponsored by Heineken UK.

Young American pianist Jonathan Biss opens The Queen’s Hall Series with Leon Kirchner’s Five Pieces, Schumann's Kreisleriana, Mozart's Adagio in B minor and Beethoven's Piano Sonata in F minor Op 57 ‘Appassionata’. Supported by The Inches Carr Trust.

event.event_code: Explorations: What do we mean by 'Postcolonial Art'?
event.event_desc: Explorations: What do we mean by 'Postcolonial Art'?
event.event_info: Professor Robert J.C. Young, a theorist, cultural critic and historian, explores the cultural legacy of colonialism and beyond. In association with British Council.

event.event_code: The Gershwins’® Porgy and Bess SM
event.event_desc: The Gershwins’® Porgy and Bess SM
event.event_info: The Gershwins' poignant tale of a decent, lonely man called Porgy and his love for the beautiful, bewitching Bess has become perhaps the quintessential American opera. In a new production for Opéra de Lyon, dynamic choreographers José Montalvo and Dominique Hervieu capture the essence of Porgy and Bess using state-of-the-art video imagery and high energy dance. Sponsored by Lloyds TSB Scotland.

Graun’s rarely-performed operatic gem is the basis for an innovative new production from one of Mexico’s most exciting young directors, Claudio Valdés Kuri. A cast of fine European and Mexican singers drawn equally from old and new worlds, are led by Ensemble Elyma and its conductor Gabriel Garrido. Supported by Embassy of Mexico, United Kingdom and CONACULTA and the Secretaría de Relaciones Exteriores, Estados Unidos Mexicanos.

In this world premiere staging from acclaimed New York ensemble Elevator Repair Service, Hemingway’s first major novel follows a group of weary, aimless and frequently inebriated American expatriates searching for identity, redemption and diversion in Europe. Audio described performance Monday 16 August 7.30pm. Supported by Edinburgh International Festival Benefactors and the Director’s Circle. With additional support from the United States Embassy, London

event.event_code: Rhapsodies in Red, White and Blue
event.event_desc: Rhapsodies in Red, White and Blue
event.event_info: The Festival goes Stateside with Gunther Schuller and the Royal Scottish National Orchestra for an evening of 20th century North American classics inspired by the pilgrims of New England, the upheavals of civil war and the spirit of prohibition. Sponsored by Prudential.

Part dance, part theatre, part ceremony, Tempest is an awe-inspiring reflection on our modern world from Samoan choreographer Lemi Ponifasio and his company MAU. This Shakespeare-inspired work explores timeless themes of political freedom and personal liberty. Supported by Visiting Arts.

Ernest Hemingway’s The Sun Also Rises and The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess are the Festival productions examined in a discussion on how innovative artists can influence and even change artforms. In association with British Council.

Carl Nielsen’s dramatic Fourth Symphony, also known as The Inextinguishable, explores the elemental life force within each of us. Sakari Oramo and the Finnish Radio Symphony Orchestra bring Nielsen’s poetic and lyrical works thrillingly to life.

With a dazzling voice, captivating presence and rare musical intelligence, Magdalena Kožená excels at interpreting the repertoire of early music and opera. This intimate recital with viol ensemble Private Musicke features music by Italian and Spanish composers. With support from Jim and Isobel Stretton.

International classical pianist Steven Osborne performs with the Royal Scottish National Orchestra in Festival 2010. In this lecture demonstration Steven explores the relevance of improvisation to classical musicians.

Prominent Mexican director Claudio Valdés Kuri talks about his experience of directing an 18th century European opera based on the story of the Aztec Emperor. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust
Exploring the late 18th century works of Roque Jacinto de Chavarría the programme for chorus, singers and instrumentalists blends ceremonial and religious music with folk songs and dances.

The Dutchman in Wagner’s Flying Dutchman has become a signature role for Finnish baritone Juha Uusitalo. Here he sings the Dutchman's Monologue alongside Wotan’s emotive Farewell from Die Walküre. Nielsen’s Fifth Symphony depicts an immense struggle for supremacy between good and evil.

Piano Concerto No 11 by Mozart and Piano Concerto No 2 by Chopin, both written in their early twenties, remain popular to this day. The rarely performed versions for string quartet and piano are played alongside Janá?ek’s Second String Quartet.

event.event_code: Behind the Scenes: Three New Ideas
event.event_desc: Behind the Scenes: Three New Ideas
event.event_info: A work-in progress, with actors performing key scenes from David Leddy's new ideas, this workshop showcases the trademark eclecticism of this Scottish writer and director.

John Collins and his company, specialists in adapting 20th century American literature for the stage, talk about the world premiere of their production of Ernest Hemingway’s The Sun Also Rises. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust
The Tallis Scholars perform a programme of choral music by Spanish renaissance composers Cristóbal de Morales and Francisco Guerrero, whose music became popular in the cathedrals of Latin America.

Samoan choreographer Lemi Ponifasio's production comes at a time of urgent and anxious debates on global warming. Birds with Skymirrors is a reflection, through beauty and stillness, on our relationship with the Earth. A co-production between Théâtre de la Ville, Theater der Welt 2010, Berliner Festspiele, Wiener Festwochen, KVS Brussels, New Zealand International Arts Festival and Holland Festival. Supported by Visiting Arts.

The first of two concerts by the mighty Cleveland Orchestra presents composing legends side by side; Ives' From the Steeples and Mountains and Bruckner's Symphony No 8. The magnificence of the Usher Hall’s organ can be heard in Joela Jones’s performance of two of Ives’s works for organ. Supported by Dunard Fund USA.

Violinist Frank Peter Zimmermann is joined by viola player Antoine Tamestit and cellist Christian Poltéra for the Festival debut of Trio Zimmermann. Beethoven’s Opus 9 String Trios are strikingly original and revealed his distinctive musical personality at an early stage.

Samoan choreographer Lemi Ponifasio, academic and poet Omar García-Obregón and Art History specialist Peter Brunt, consider the voice of exclusion and exile in the New World. In association with British Council.
The American mezzo soprano talks about her sparkling international career. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust

event.event_code: Sacred Music from Lisbon to Rio de Janeiro
event.event_desc: Sacred Music from Lisbon to Rio de Janeiro
event.event_info: Director Bruno Procopio, with his choir and instrumental ensemble, takes a musical journey from Portugal to Brazil. The concert includes the extraordinary requiem by 19th century native Brazilian composer José Maurício Nunes Garcia and Haydn’s Missa Brevis written in honour of the Portuguese friar Saint João Cidade, St John of God.

In the second of their Festival 2010 performances, the Cleveland Orchestra presents extracts from Korngold's lush 1920 opera Die tote Stadt, Berg's Lulu Suite and Brahms' Symphony No 2 in D. Supported by Dunard Fund USA.

Just 25 years old, Edicson Ruiz is establishing his credentials as a master of the double bass. At just 17 Ruiz became the first Latin American, and youngest-ever, member of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra. Teaming up with Sergio Tiempo, he will have The Queen’s Hall moving to the South American rhythms of Ginastera and Piazzolla. With support from Mr and Mrs James Anderson.

event.event_code: Behind the Scenes: The Mass Observation Project
event.event_desc: Behind the Scenes: The Mass Observation Project
event.event_info: In 1937, a wide ranging project called ‘Mass Observation’ was set up by the UK Government, investigating ‘the science of the everyday’ by observing and recording the lives of ordinary people in Britain. In 2010, this research continues. With bold and evocative lighting and sound, young London based theatre company, Inspector Sands, draws on this rich archive to offer the first glimpse of an ambitious new project.

Florilegium, one of Britain’s foremost baroque ensembles, is joined by a quartet of young Bolivian singers in music recently unearthed from the Christian missions of Chiquitos and Moxos Indians in eastern Bolivia.

Noted for its memorable melodies and lively interplay between soloist and orchestra, Tchaikovsky’s Violin Concerto is in the hands of one of the great violin virtuosos of our time, Vadim Repin. Shostakovich's Symphony No 15, along with the Russian National Orchestra’s impassioned strings, spiky brass and crashing percussion it combines to deliver a compelling and illuminating performance. Supported by Dunard Fund USA.
After their critically acclaimed 2008 Festival performance, Pavel Haas Quartet return to Festival 2010 with a programme which includes Dvo?ák’s American Quartet.
Founders of Brazilian contemporary dance company Grupo Corpo, Rodrigo and Paulo Pederneiras, discuss their beliefs and inspirations. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust
A concert of music by Tomás Luis de Victoria and Juan Gutiérrez de Padilla, two great renaissance composers from Spain.

Sir Charles Mackerras leads the Scottish Chamber Orchestra and Chorus in a concert performance of this masterpiece of opera seria.This is undoubtedly one of Mozart’s greatest operatic achievements. Concert performance sung in Italian. Supported by The Binks Trust.

Building on a solid foundation of classical movement, Grupo Corpo’s high-octane ensemble of dancers combines the sensual elements inherent in Brazilian popular dance with cutting-edge contemporary dance techniques. Sponsored by Baillie Gifford Investment Managers.
Sarah Connolly, one of Britain’s greatest mezzo sopranos, returns to her roots in a concert dedicated to British and American songs from the 1930s and 40s.

Since graduating from the BBC’s New Generation Artists scheme, Christianne Stotijn has gone on to establish herself as one of the most exciting and sought after singers of her generation. 2010 sees her Festival debut with regular collaborator Joseph Breinl.
David Harrington, John Sherba, Hank Dutt and Jeffrey Zeigler talk about the singular artistic vision of the Kronos Quartet. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust.

Caledonia is a new play by celebrated playwright and satirist Alistair Beaton on William Paterson, a financial adventurer who in 1698 devised one of the most daring and disastrous speculations of all time - to found a Scottish colony in Darien on the isthmus of Panama in Central America and turn Scotland, one of the poorest nations in Europe, into a prosperous colonial power. A co-production between the Edinburgh International Festival and the National Theatre of Scotland. Captioned performance Tuesday 24 August 7.30pm. BSL interpreted and audio described performance Wednesday 25 August 7.30pm. Touch tour Wednesday 25 August 6.30pm. Supported through the Scottish Government’s Edinburgh Festivals Expo Fund.

In this production, the New York-based Wooster Group forges a new mode of expression for Tennessee Williams' lyric voice. It tells the story of a young writer who makes his home amongst restless young malcontents and elderly eccentrics. As he becomes entangled with their lives, his own fate reveals itself. Commissioned by Théâtre National de Strasbourg, Wiener Festwochen, Les Spectacles Vivants – Centre Pompidou and Festival d’Automne à Paris. Audio described performance Tuesday 24 August 7.30pm. Please note this production contains adult themes. Supported by the United States Embassy, London.

Gospel music, rock ‘n’ roll swagger, a dash of soul and syncopated style are at the heart of this uplifting spectacle by Lee Breuer and Bob Telson. Set in modern day America it is a radical reworking of Sophocles' tragedy Oedipus at Colonus. The wonderful traditions of gospel singing are centre stage and will have you jumping out of your seat to join in! Sponsored by Standard Life.

With a fearless drive to expand the range and context of the string quartet, the Kronos Quartet is one of the most celebrated and influential ensembles of today. This is chamber music on a grand scale – colourful, imaginative, provocative and sure to set the expansive acoustic of the Usher Hall ablaze.

Professor Paul Carter, interdisciplinary scholar at the University of Melbourne, talks about living in a culture not your own and its implications for one’s sense of place and belonging. In association with British Council.

The River People have developed a distinct style of theatre with puppetry, folk storytelling and live music. Little Matter, a performance work-in-progress, explores an individual’s place in the universe and the search for the self combining the influences of mythology, quantum physics and William Blake.

Building on a solid foundation of classical movement, Grupo Corpo’s high-octane ensemble of dancers combines the sensual elements inherent in Brazilian popular dance with cutting-edge contemporary dance techniques. Sponsored by Baillie Gifford Investment Managers.

Joyce DiDonato is among the world’s most enchanting performers. In this concert her performance includes works by Italians Pergolesi, Caccini and Leoncavallo alongside Spanish repertoire by Granados, Obradors and Montsalvatge.
Simon Keenlyside, accompanied by Malcolm Martineau on piano, performs a selection of songs from Ned Rorem, Butterworth and Schumann's Dichterliebe.
For over thirty years they have been reinventing theatre. Elizabeth LeCompte and members of The Wooster Group discuss their latest work. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust.

The choir and instrumentalists of early music specialists Ex Cathedra present a programme following the structure of the Vespers Service with baroque and renaissance music from Mexico, Bolivia and Peru.

event.event_code: La fanciulla del West (The Girl of the Golden West)
event.event_desc: La fanciulla del West (The Girl of the Golden West)
event.event_info: Puccini's fast moving tale of love, jealousy, gambling, banditry and violence and their effect on a tight knit community. Performance sung in Italian. Supported by The Stevenston Charitable Trust with additional support from The Italian Cultural Institute, Edinburgh.

After their critically acclaimed 2008 Festival performance Pavel Haas Quartet return to Festival 2010. Their programme includes the second string quartet by Pavel Haas From the Monkey Mountains, Britten's youthful Divertimenti and the first of Beethoven's great Razumovsky quartets, demonstrating this youthful quartet's immense versatility and virtuosity.

One of the world’s greatest proponents of early European music, Harry Christophers and members of his ensemble invite us to join them in a conversation about their work. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust.

Playwright and journalist Alistair Beaton joins Tom Devine, Professor of Scottish History, University of Edinburgh and economist Dr Gary Shea, University of St Andrews, to discuss Scotland’s failed foray into colonialism. In association with British Council.

Writer Alistair Beaton and director Anthony Neilson talk about the extraordinary story of the Darien scheme, Scotland’s ill fated Central American colony, and its relevance today. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust.

Jordi Savall and his vocal and instrumental ensembles return to the Festival with the music of fire and air; a celebration of over 200 years of musical meeting points between ancient Iberia and the ‘New World’ from the 16th century onward.

Set in the royal courts of Peru and Mexico just prior to the arrival of the Spanish Conquistadors, The Indian Queen is an intricate tale of dynastic power and regal heritage. Following the memorable success of their performance of The Fairy Queen in 2009, Harry Christophers and The Sixteen return to the Usher Hall to delight us in a programme containing immortal anthems and delightful occasional music. Sponsored by Classic FM.
Gerald Finley, accompanied by pianist Julius Drake, performs an entertaining selection of music from Europe and the United States including songs by Schumann, Ravel, Barber and Ives.

A work-in-progress, this adaptation of Bram Stoker’s chilling tale emerges from the Victorian obsession with the occult. A daring re-imagining of a classic and a bold investigation into the concept of storytelling with the added bite of shoddy commercial showmanship. Belt Up Theatre’s practice explores the possibilities of immersive theatre.
A rare opportunity as Midori joins us to talk about what, from a very early age, has been a remarkable international career. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust.

Stéphane Denève leads the Royal Scottish National Orchestra and a wonderful cast in Ravel's superbly witty, comic masterpiece, that delights the ear in its affection for the colours and sonorous contours of all things Spanish. Performance sung in French. Made possible by a legacy from Ronald Alexander Miller Mackenzie, FRICS.
Midori makes her Festival debut with a programme which juxtaposes two well known violin sonatas by Beethoven and Brahms with two 20th century works by Bloch and Davidovsky.
Iconic American artist Meredith Monk shares her distinctive philosophies on life. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust.

In their UK debut, choreographer Alonzo King and his Lines Ballet from San Francisco bring a pair of works to the Festival which show the vulnerability and tenderness of his choreography alongside the furious abandon and exhilarating freedom of his company’s contemporary classical style. Sponsored by Lloyds TSB Scotland. Supported by Léan Scully EIF Fund.

The Scottish National Jazz Orchestra, lead by Tommy Smith and conducted by Gunther Schuller, performs a programme of music from jazz luminaries Duke Ellington, Count Basie and Dizzy Gillespie. Joe Lavano joins the orchestra celebrating great, big band, jazz music: unexplored and traditional; universal and native; emphatic and reflective.

The Nash Ensemble present works inspired by jazz rhythms. They will perform Bartók's Contrasts, Gershwin's Lullaby for string quartet, Copland's Sextet and Dvo?ák's String Quintet in E fl at Op 97 ‘American’.

event.event_code: Zakir Hussain Master of the Tabla
event.event_desc: Zakir Hussain Master of the Tabla
event.event_info: One of the world leading tabla players, Zakir Hussain appears with Alonzo King Lines Ballet in Festival 2010. In this lecture demonstration Zakir offers rare insights into the music and culture of this iconic instrument.
Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Gunther Schuller shares his experiences from a most remarkable and fascinating musical career that ranges from the orchestral platform to the jazz club.

The fascinating contrasts and complexities of Brazil form the inspiration for Água. Pina Bausch's charismatic and eclectic company of dancers transports you from beach to rainforest and then back again in a playful work brimming with joie de vivre. Audio described performance Sunday 29th August.

Having taken up his post as Principal Conductor with the Scottish Chamber Orchestra in 2009, Robin Ticciati makes his Festival debut with the world premiere of Kevin Volan's Symphony: Daar Kom die Alibama, performed along with Poulenc's Concerto for two pianos and Bizet's Symphony in C. With support from Donald and Louise MacDonald. Supported by Culture Ireland.
John Etheridge brings his quartet Sweet Chorus to the Festival, paying homage to jazz legends guitarist Django Reinhardt and violinist Stephane Grappelli.

event.event_code: Ll?r Williams, Juliette Bausor, Jane Atkins
event.event_desc: Ll?r Williams, Juliette Bausor, Jane Atkins
event.event_info: Ll?r Williams, accompanied by Juliette Bausor and Jane Atkins on flute and viola, perform Beethoven's Piano Sonata in E flat and Ives' Piano Sonata No 2 ‘Concord’. With support from Joscelyn Fox.

American choreographer Alonzo King talks with academic Roman Krznaric and Judith Robertson, Director of Oxfam Scotland, about empathy, change and new global perspectives. In association with British Council.

Stravinsky’s baroque-inspired Dumbarton Oaks is a celebration of the music and culture of New England, USA. Virtuoso violinist Midori performs Bernstein’s Serenade which the composer himself described as a ‘series of related statements in praise of love’. Dvo?ák’s lyrical New World Symphony was intended to celebrate the fourth centenary of Columbus’s ‘discovery’ of America.

Sin Sangre by Teatro Cinema from Chile is an adaptation of a novella by Italian author and playwright Alessandro Baricco, with all the darkness and tension of a 1960s B-movie thriller. A fast paced production combining intense dialogue and raw action with widescreen cinematic projection. Performed in Spanish with English supertitles. Sponsored by Pinsent Masons.

Where one artform stops and another starts has never been a concern for Meredith Monk as she seamlessly blends elements of music, art and theatre to startling effect. Part uplifting celebration, part devotional ritual, Songs of Ascension is an ethereal, meditative work that combines music, movement and film. Supported by the American Friends of the Edinburgh International Festival. With additional support from the United States Embassy London.
In this solo concert Etheridge roams across Africa, Europe and America with music that includes gypsy tunes, jazz riffs, metallic blues and his famed improvisations.

event.event_code: Explorations: New voices from the landscape
event.event_desc: Explorations: New voices from the landscape
event.event_info: Professor Catherine Boyle, King’s College London, Dr Fiona Mackintosh, University of Edinburgh and Chilean based writer Odette Magnet explore the cultural landscape of South America. In association with British Council.
Choreographer Alonzo King, a distinctive voice in dance, talks about how he embraces a global perspective on stage. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust.

The Minnesota Orchestra ranks among America’s top symphonic ensembles. Conducted by Osmo Vänskä it performs Beethoven's Seventh Symphony along works from Barber and Elgar. Supported by Dunard Fund USA.

This original and poetic story makes the very most of Teatro Cinema's celebrated striking visual style blending film and live action. Brave and ambitious, The Man Who Fed Butterflies asks questions about the true potential of the human mind. Performed in Spanish with English supertitles. A co-production between Edinburgh International Festival, Teatro Cinema, Santiago a Mil, Scène Nationale de Sète, Centre Dramatique Le Manège, Napoli Teatro Festival and Fondo Para El Desarrollo de Las Artes (Chilean Government). Sponsored by Pinsent Masons.

Pioneering classical accordionist James Crabb is one of the world’s leading exponents of the instrument. He is joined by classical guitarist George Vassilev. The sexy, seductive sounds of South America resonate around The Hub with works by Argentinean composers Astor Piazzolla and Tomas Gubitsch.

event.event_code: Joan Rodgers, Roderick Williams, Roger Vignoles
event.event_desc: Joan Rodgers, Roderick Williams, Roger Vignoles
event.event_info: Accompanied by Roger Vignoles on piano, acclaimed baritone Roderick Williams and star of the opera stage and concert platform Joan Rodgers perform a programme of duets and solo songs from Mills' Songlines of the Heart’s Desire, Wolf's Italienisches Liederbuch, Schumann and Brahms. Supported by the Victorian Government through Arts Victoria.

A welcome return to the Festival for this great orchestra. The magical combination of the Concertgebouw, conductor Mariss Jansons and an eclectic and invigorating programme with works from Stravinsky, Bartók and Berio is sure to ignite. Sponsored by City Inn Contemporary Hotels.
A solo recital in which James Crabb performs works by US composers John Zorn and Aaron Copland alongside the passionate music of Astor Piazzolla.
Presenting pieces from Joplin, Gershwin, Peterson, Ravel, Rachmaninov and others, Steven Osborne performs one of the most eclectic programmes at this year’s Festival.

event.event_code: Explorations: A Scotsman's legacy to Australasia
event.event_desc: Explorations: A Scotsman's legacy to Australasia
event.event_info: Her Excellency Professor Marie Bashir, 37th Governor of New South Wales, explores Scot Lachlan Macquarie’s contribution to Australia, in the company of one of his descendants, Ken MacQuarrie, Controller, BBC Scotland. In association with British Council.
Director Dauno Tótoro and film director Juan Carlos Zagal of Chilean ensemble Teatro Cinema talk about their remarkable fusion of artforms. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust.

In their second performance at this year's Festival, the Concertgebouw and Mariss Jansons present Mahler's Symphony No 3, a monumental hymn to the natural world uses dynamic vocal forces to create one of the most exceptional symphonies in the repertoire. Sponsored by Lloyds TSB Scotland.

A who’s who of influential contemporary American composers alongside young Australasians makes for a distinctive and exciting choral concert, including Ross Edwards's Sacred Kingfisher Psalms, a co-commission between the Edinburgh International Festival, Canberra International Music Festival and Ars Nova Copenhagen.

The eminent Russian-born conductor and pianist Vladimir Ashkenazy brings Australia’s premiere orchestra to Edinburgh for two Festival performances. Two of Elgar’s most popular works sit alongside two modern works by Australian composers Peter Sculthorpe and Ross Edwards. Sponsored by ARUP.
Tokyo Quartet perform string quartets from Debussy and Schubert along with the European premiere of Sculthorpe's String Quartet No 1, commissioned by the Edinburgh International Festival.
Grammy award-winning mezzo soprano Susan Graham talks about how she is equally at home on the concert stage and in the recording studio. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust.

Bliss is a much-anticipated new operatic collaboration with all the ingredients for excitement: a score by Brett Dean, an enthralling libretto by Amanda Holden, the directorial wit and sparkle of Neil Armfield, the virtuosity of Elgar Howarth and the BBC Symphony Orchestra and the electrifying stage presence of Peter Coleman-Wright, based on Peter Carey’s remarkable novel. Contains coarse language and adult themes. Supported by Edinburgh International Festival Friends and Patrons and the Victorian Government through Arts Victoria.

In the second of their Festival performances, the orchestra perform Ravel's jazz influenced Piano Concerto in G, Matthew Hindson's Energy, Sibelius' Rakastava and Der Rosenkavalier Suite from Strauss' best loved opera.

Teatro en el Blanco from Santiago, making its Edinburgh debut at the Festival 2010, presents visceral and emotive theatre. Diciembre is blackly comic, exploring the divisive nature of war for both a country and a family. Performed in Spanish with English supertitles. Sponsored by The List.

Paco Peña creates a new work for Festival 2010 through the powerful storytelling of flamenco music and dance. Quimeras brings to life the journeys of migrants and refugees, reflecting both good and bad aspects of their dreams, the reality of their lives and their connection with the people on the other side of the frontiers they cross. A co-production between the Edinburgh International Festival and Paco Peña Flamenco Dance Company. Sponsored by Standard Life.
Duo Sol brings a flamboyant programme of music from the new world together with Beethoven’s dazzling Kreutzer Sonata. Supported by the Victorian Government through Arts Victoria.

Director of Diciembre, Guillermo Calderón, novelist Susan Elderkin and Neil Armfield, director of Opera Australia’s production of Bliss, discuss how lost narratives surface in artistic expression. In association with British Council.

Writer and director Guillermo Calderón is joined by his cast Jorge Becker, Trinidad Jansana, Paula Zúñiga, to talk about their bitter comic production, Diciembre. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust

Now a firm Festival favourite, American mezzo soprano Susan Graham is one of the world’s foremost opera and recital stars. Tonight she performs a sumptuous programme of music by American composers alongside songs by Mozart and Mahler. With support from Frank Hitchman.

In the final concert of The Queen’s Hall Series the Simón Bolívar String Quartet performs a programme featuring music from South America alongside works by Bach, Brahms and Shostakovich. This concert promises to finish the Festival on a high. Supported by The Peter Diamand Trust.

This original and poetic story makes the very most of Teatro Cinema's celebrated striking visual style blending film and live action. Brave and ambitious, The Man Who Fed Butterflies asks questions about the true potential of the human mind. Performed in Spanish with English supertitles. A co-production between Edinburgh International Festival, Teatro Cinema, Santiago a Mil, Scène Nationale de Sète, Centre Dramatique Le Manège, Napoli Teatro Festival and Fondo Para El Desarrollo de Las Artes (Chilean Government). Sponsored by Pinsent Masons.
Master of flamenco style and virtuoso guitarist Paco Peña talks about creating a new production for the Festival. Supported by Gordon Fraser Charitable Trust.

Teatro en el Blanco from Santiago, making its Edinburgh debut at the Festival 2010, presents visceral and emotive thetare. Diciembre is blackly comic, exploring the divisive nature of war for both a country and a family. Performed in Spanish with English supertitles. Sponsored by The List.

Mahler’s self-proclaimed 'Symphony of a Thousand' is an epic climax to the Festival’s 2010 Usher Hall programme. Donald Runnicles leads the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra, a stellar cast of soloists, the Edinburgh Festival Chorus and the Royal Scottish National Orchestra Junior Chorus in Mahler’s heavenly Eighth Symphony. Sponsored by Lumison.

Join the Scottish Chamber Orchestra for a spectacular evening of American film music with carefully choreographed pyrotechnics for a rousing finale to the 2010 Festival. Hollywood offers up a perfect opportunity for the masters of fireworks design, Pyrovision, to paint the Edinburgh skyline in cinematic style. Sponsored by Bank of Scotland.
